body:
@ZuluPro Thanks.

Is it possible to get a test Cloudwatt account / credentials? I would like to test this driver before merging those changes into trunk.
Thanks, changes look good to me.
Sorry for the delay. I've merged changes into trunk. Thanks.
/cc @Kami - mind giving us your thoughts on this?

Will dig in ASAP.

On a related note - we already have an establish pattern for handling paginated collections which should probably also work here. See https://github.com/apache/libcloud/blob/trunk/libcloud/dns/drivers/zerigo.py#L149 for an example.
Ah, good point. Reminded me that the Google DNS driver also uses generators: https://github.com/apache/libcloud/blob/trunk/libcloud/dns/drivers/google.py
Merged into trunk. Thanks.

Ah, didn't see that. It looks like this would be the first time iterate_\* is used in the compute driver.

It would be pretty easy to overlay the iterate_\* functions on top of GCEList if my underlying approach is still sound. This would keep the filter functionality available in ex_list().

Alternatively we could establish a pattern for filter, too.
Thanks. I will look into it shortly.
Haven't forgotten, but didn't get to it yet. My apologies!
Fixed a typo and merged changes into trunk. Thanks.

Hi @phildav - thanks for the contribution!

As you can see, `create_node` is becoming quite cluttered and tricky to keep updated with GCE API changes and ensure backwards compatibility.  Thats why, in a recent change, I punted on providing new arguments for things like local SSD and instead just allowed for a generic JSON/python argument `ex_disks_gce_struct`.  The idea obviously is to let the programmer specify anything here that the upstream GCE API accepts for disks.

I can understand philosophically in wanting new params for local ssd and disk size, but it's not strictly necessary, correct?

Also, if we go with this pull-request, I'd like to see tests (and rigorous ones) that ensure backwards compatibility.

Hi @erjohnso , thank you for the quick reply.
The reason why I added this into libcloud is that I'm using salt cloud, and it's not aware of `ex_disks_gce_struct`. Building this structure is not totally obvious since it require to know what gce expects. Although it does not belong to the list of features in common with other clouds, my feeling is that it make sense to have this in libcloud instead of its multiple users.
Let me know which direction you want to go with this PR: write specific tests, rework disk options or close it and wait for a better idea...

Hi @phildav 

My preference would be to see `salt-cloud` extended to support a `local-ssd` type,

https://github.com/saltstack/salt/blob/develop/salt/cloud/clouds/gce.py#L2047

which I think would be cleaner from a Salt user's perspective (rather than requiring them to specify a new attribute/parameter).

But, this would then require and update to the GCE driver to properly format the `ex_disks_gce_struct` and adding that to `**kwargs` before creating the new VM,

https://github.com/saltstack/salt/blob/develop/salt/cloud/clouds/gce.py#L2047

I know it's a bit more work inside salt-cloud, but I do think it's cleaner that way.

wdyt?

Sure it can be done in salt-cloud. But then every client of libcloud who wants to support these options has to know
- how to build the `ex_disks_gce_struct` properly
- resolve diskType and image links with `ex_get_disktype` and `ex_get_image`
- how to build the request to get local SSD to work (took me a few tries).

For what it's worth (I'm not a long time user of libcloud), since it's not trivial to build this `ex_disks_gce_struct` structure then I would put that code in common.
I agree that `create_node` may not be the best place if that piece of code gets large, so maybe we can add a helper that creates `ex_disks_gce_struct` properly in libcloud so it's available for every user ?

Thanks.

As mentioned on IRC, I'm pretty busy these days, but I will try to have a look ASAP.
No problem. Thanks for merging!
Thanks! At the moment at OpenStack upstream we're writing a guide (I think you're going to like it!) which relies on libcloud, including the swift bits, so getting this in soon-ish would be handy :)
I'm uncertain if my use of check on `force_ipv4` is valid. When IPv4 isn't forced, that doesn't mean it's not allowed; right?
OK, thanks.

@fifieldt Awesome, great to hear that :)

Do let us know if there is anything we can to do make the experience better / more pleasant. And as always, contributions are welcome :)
Also, fix merged into trunk. Thanks.

Thanks for the PR.

There is already a similar PR which tries to address that - #343. We should figure out how to consolidate those two and get it merged.

I personally think approach in #343 is better start since it handles this difference in the function where this problem can arise.

What do you think?

Sorry everyone for the delay. The pull request and the patch itself is just big and I'm busy and had problems finding a big enough chunk of time which would allow me to thoroughly review the changes.

I finally started working on it today though. I created a new branch based on this pull request where I will push any cleanup or changes which are needed (I will open a new PR shortly). Hopefully patch will finally land in trunk soon.
Lets continue in #499.
Thanks, I will have a look shortly (will most likely have time to review this one before autoscaling changes since it's a smaller patch which doesn't introduce any new APIs and requires less work).

@phildav - sorry for the lag.

I'm OK moving forward with your approach to extend libcloud's `create()` call extended to include local-ssd, but would like to see some stringent tests included.  When it comes time to roll this up into `salt-cloud`, I'd still suggest exposing it as `local-ssd` to the user as I suggested versus setting a new param.

- move `run_test.sh` to `contrib`
- added onapp doc, with example
- removed unused methods
- shortened helper method

Great, thanks.

I will review it and add the comments inline.

I have moved autoscale support to a new 'autoscale' folder per your recommendation in IRC. This is done under a new PR, with the same title, that I have just opened.

I will be happy to get your comments.
Great, thanks.

Great, thanks.

Are you planning to open a new PR?

Thanks - the change looks good to me.

Can you please also add some documentation on how to use docker to run the tests to `docs/testing.rst`.

I'm wondering if the hack is what is causing the provider feature matrix build to fail.

https://github.com/jcastillo2nd/libcloud/blob/trunk/contrib/generate_provider_feature_matrix_table.py#L224

Should this also include a check if this is node driver vs dns driver to let the normal driver selector hit without overriding?

```
        elif name.lower() == 'digital_ocean' and api != 'dns':
```
@Kami, Sorry, my account is only for work purpose, Maybe you can ask them one account with notoriety of libcloud ?

Great, thanks!

I will have a look asap.

I'm thinking the hack can be removed entirely since the DigitalOceanNodeDriver can handle both cases with just passing of the secret or key only:

```
>>> from libcloud.compute.drivers.digitalocean import DigitalOceanNodeDriver
>>> n1 = DigitalOceanNodeDriver('v1_key', 'v1_secret')
>>> n1.__class__
<class 'libcloud.compute.drivers.digitalocean.DigitalOcean_v1_NodeDriver'>
>>> n2 = DigitalOceanNodeDriver('v2_key')
>>> n2.__class__
<class 'libcloud.compute.drivers.digitalocean.DigitalOcean_v2_NodeDriver'>
```

Also, I'm pulling the ex_ssh functions back into the v1 driver to live alongside the key pair functions so it doesn't break existing functionality. Poor foresight on my part.

Looks like removing the hack worked as it handles the tests properly for both v1 and v2 cases in DigitalOceanNodeDriver, also the old ex_ssh_\* functions have been restored to v1, but with warnings.warn regarding deprecation.

This looks good from a working build perspective, let me know if there is anything else needed on this.

Added some docs (ccc53c5202f5aae7fd0e5ad3bf64d26ed3a4681a) and merged changes into trunk.

Thanks.

Made some minor style and Python 3 compatibility fixes and merged changes into trunk.

Thanks!

Hi, can we close corresponding issue: https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LIBCLOUD-688 ?

Thanks.
friendly ping and just checking in to make sure nothing is blocked on me.
@erjohnso can you please review this one and take it across the finish line?
@verb Sorry for the delay. I have quickly glanced over it and it looks good to me, but I haven't done any testing.

Looks good, merged into trunk.

Thanks.

P.S. Can you please close the PR (I forgot to do it in the commit message).

Thanks.

Hm, I just had a look at the code and it seems like we should never end up in a scenario when `_stream_data` is called with `data` argument which would result in iterator being exhausted twice. In short, your code should be unnecessary (it seems to just be working around a deeper bug / problem somewhere else).

In case `data` is provided, `_upload_data` method should be called and not `_stream_data`.

Can you please also provide a specific piece of code which reproduces this scenario? Thanks.

Thanks.

It appears the code is actually working as intended - in case there are multiple pages, we don't want to break out of the loop. We just want to update the `marker` query string parameter which will result in us retrieving results from the next page and eventually when we are on the last page either one of the following termination conditions should be reached:
- No content status code is returned.
- There are no more objects on the last page.

Having said that, there might actually be a bug in how we handle the last page. I will look into trying to reproduce that case (multiple pages, last page has >= 1 objects).

It would also help if you can gist the output of running your code which results in an infinite loop using `LIBCLOUD_DEBUG`.
Sorry for the delay and thanks. Would it be possible for us to get a test account so we can test out the changes on a real installation?

Overall, after quickly glancing over it, the changes look good.

Can you please add some documentation to `docs/compute/drivers/` (see existing driver / provider documentation for an example)?

I've added some comments.

Overall the PR looks good, but there are some small things which need to be addressed so we can get it merged.
@MatthiasWiesnerCC bump^^
Closing the PR, as tests got integrated.

Commit added to pull request with changes on casing, docstrings and kwargs refactoring. Will work on the documentation side now.

https://github.com/DimensionDataCBUSydney/libcloud/commit/7faa26f8b14bb5cbf5ea6f0ce4a829cc2ba4ef27

Documentation edits have been contributed back to the branch.

Please let me know if we can move ahead.

@tonybaloney Thanks, changes look good.

Can you please squash the commits and I will go ahead and merge it into trunk.

Can you please provide more context and background on this change - why is it needed? what breaks with it? regression test? etc.

Thanks :)

This is the squashed commit. 
https://github.com/DimensionDataCBUSydney/libcloud/commit/c2b4ba6669851294cb5f76cc82aa5b7e9f4a3345
Patch diff file attached to jira ticket: https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LIBCLOUD-698

This fix was required for me in order for ec2 Frankfurt to work (uses signature_version 4). I noticed that under circumstances of running connections in parallel it would use signature_version 2 (and thus fail to authenticate), and it has worked without problems with this small patch (also in other regions as well). Unfortunately I cannot be explicit on how to reproduce the bug though
Merged into trunk. Thanks.

@mgogoulos Alright, thanks.

I thought those issues shouldn't happen anymore since we now use `_ex_connection_kwargs` instead of class variables, but there might still be a bug hiding somewhere in that code so I will dig in and try to reproduce the issue and find the root cause.

Thanks.

Can you please clarify what you mean with "not implemented yet"?

Sorry for the delay.

Changes look good and have been merged into trunk. Thanks.
Merged into trunk. Thanks.

I based it on the joyent driver, which follows a similar pattern (so of note that one may suffer the same issue!).

Running DimensionData and Rackspace side by side does give results for the DimensionData driver, then 
    pprint(driver.list_nodes())
NameError: name 'driver' is not defined

Will follow the EC2 pattern instead and resubmit changes

Updated and tested against multiple regions in the same process by: 

DimensionData = get_driver(Provider.DIMENSIONDATA)

drivers = [DimensionData('anthony','****_',region='dd-na'),
           DimensionData('anthony','**_**',region='dd-au')]

for driver in drivers:
     nodes = driver.list_nodes()
     print(len(nodes))

Gives 14 and 154 as expected.

@tonybaloney Thanks, I will have a look.

Also, to clarify it, your example wouldn't uncover the bug. You would need to do something like this:

``` python
driver1 = cls(region='region-1')
driver2 = cls(region='region-2')

pprint(driver1.list_nodes())
pprint(driver2.list_nodes())
pprint(driver1.list_nodes())  # If there is a bug, this line would result in region from driver2 also being used here
```

Hi, 
Any update on this PR? I don't know why it failed on Travis, it works fine for me.
Sorry for the delay, @verb!  Thanks!!

Forgot to close this via commit message... merged upstream.

https://git-wip-us.apache.org/repos/asf?p=libcloud.git;a=commit;h=5c1a95bf199094008c682d3cffab560095668ceb
Flaky SoftLayer test. My tox tests passed locally, so I merged.

print(len(driver1.list_nodes()))
print(len(driver2.list_nodes()))
print(len(driver1.list_nodes()))

gives 5, 154 and 5, so its not giving that bug
Good catch. Will merge.

This also fixes #511.

@allardhoeve Please make sure to give credit to both people when updating changelog - thanks :)

Thanks for the report.

Looking at the issue it seems more like a problem with the response getting corrupted and not an issue with the actual library we use to decompress the response - that is why thee CRC exists in the first place - to make sure the data is intact and not corrupted.

If it was an issue with a library, it would fail all of the time, not just some times. It could be a some kind of network issue on your or CloudSigma's side, a loadbalancer at CloudSigma corrupting the response or something else in the middle causing this issue to happen.

Only thing I find weird is that using zlib doesn't cause this issue to happen. Python zlib library should still include a CRC.

In any case, I will dig in and also try to reproduce the issue myself.

/cc @vpetersson

Thanks.

Will wait for @vpetersson's response about the new mapping for the "unavailable" state. The pause one looks good to me though.

Thanks.

I will have a look asap.

@Kami 'unavailable' is a tricky one. In most cases, it's just a temporary error, but it's really a catch-all error when we're able to get the proper status from the host. Perhaps @gcbirzan can chime in with a more detailed explanation.
Merged into trunk. Thanks.

Fixed lint (9f21f1f91a2dd35b34f37d322f2dd2e75cc3caa3) and Python 2.5 version compatibility issue (635c34e06ab86b91ce4648aa8212b71361c2afe1), added a test case (635c34e06ab86b91ce4648aa8212b71361c2afe1) and merged change into trunk.

The lint issue was related to lines being longer than 80 characters.

Thanks.
@jcastillo2nd Sorry for the delay and please ping me when those comments are addressed - I would love to get this change included in the next release.

I made a minor change (use normal dictionary access instead of get - we should throw if dictionary doesn't contain "host" item since this most likely indicates a programmer error) and merged changes into trunk.

Thanks.

From what I understand, unavailable is indeed usually a temporary status,
but while a server is in state unavailable, no API actions can be taken on
it (API returns a 500 error when attempting to interact with an unavailable
sever), thus why I figured ERROR would be the best state map for it.
Hopefully Cristian has something to say about this though :)

Just curious, does NodeState.ERROR usually imply an unrecoverable error?

On Sat, May 16, 2015, 21:17 Viktor Petersson notifications@github.com
wrote:

> @Kami https://github.com/Kami 'unavailable' is a tricky one. In most
> cases, it's just a temporary error, but it's really a catch-all error when
> we're able to get the proper status from the host. Perhaps @gcbirzan
> https://github.com/gcbirzan can chime in with a more detailed
> explanation.
> 
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/apache/libcloud/pull/517#issuecomment-102667485.

I would agree with you, but we've been polling CloudSigma's API with gzip
request/response headers (specifically the /servers/detail/?limit=0 action)
every few minutes for a while now using curl's decompression library, and
haven't had any issues.  Also, while debugging this issue, the compressed
response data is complete when decompressed with command line gzip (but
it's missing the EOF?).

Granted, it is strange that there's no complaints about it with other
drivers. If you need any other info to help troubleshoot, let me know.  In
the meantime I'll do some testing in other environments on the off chance
that something's off with mine.

On Sat, May 16, 2015, 21:12 Tomaz Muraus notifications@github.com wrote:

> Thanks for the report.
>

> getting corrupted and not an issue with the actual library we use to

> https://github.com/apache/libcloud/pull/519#issuecomment-102667197.

@chrisob Yeah, ERROR usually implies an end state which is not recoverable.

I don't think we have any detailed docs on the states right now, but I will make sure they get added.

@chrisob Alright, thanks.

I will also apply try to reproduce the issue you have encountered and test your patch.

Really sorry for the long delay (we don't get notifications when you push commits so I didn't notice that you updated the PR).

In any case, this change has finally been merged now. Thanks again.

@ZuluPro I've made some changes so it works with the latest OpenStack auth refactoring (8aa3e27563970decd851ca84672562a41e53ef0a) and merged changes into trunk.

Next time please make sure you create a branch for your changes and don't directly commit to trunk - this will make it easier for both of us (this time, I needed to do some git foo and rebase to get it into mergable state).

Please also submit a new pull request which inclues documentation and usage examples for the driver (see `libcloud/compute/drivers`*.rst` for an examples) - driver without documentation (and tests) is not really useful.

Thanks.

Thanks @smstone!

This looks good to me, but could you please rebase and squash into a single commit?
@erjohnso I rebased and squashed, PTAL. Thanks.
Merged into trunk. Thanks.

Thanks.

Can you please provide more context - I assume this only affects Python >= 3.3 and the latest version of 2.7 (2.7.9) with the backported SSL changes?

I have faxed in my ICLA today as well. Thanks!
